summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment in favor of a class action brought by a former Citi employee alleging that he or she violated the fiduciary duties of the Citi Institutional Liquid Reserves Fund.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed on September 8, 2015, filed in federal district court in Manhattan, Marya J. Leber, Sara L. Kennedy, and Sherri M. Harris violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The complaint alleges that defendants failed to adequately monitor the performance of the Plan and failed to take reasonable steps to remediate the issues raised in the complaint.  In addition, the complaint alleged that defendants violated Rule 23(b)(3) by failing to adequately report material losses to the Plan's investment committee, which included Leber and Kennedy.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint, the defendants have consented to the entry of judgments permanently enjoining them from future violations of the federal securities laws, ordering them to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and imposing civil penalties against each of them.  On September 19, 2017, the court granted a temporary restraining order against the defendants from further violating the securities laws and ordered the SEC to conduct an independent examination of the claims of the class members.  A hearing on September 21, 2017 was scheduled for 7:30 p.m. Eastern.  To learn more about class actions, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-5221 (Aug. 24, 2015).  The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.  Investors can also use theÂ SEC'sÂ Adviser.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.Â The SEC's Complaint, filed under seal on Sept. 5, 2016, charges the defendants with violating Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4)-8 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 206(3)-8 thereunder, and seeks a permanent injunction against future violations.  For further information, see Investor Alert:Â Securities Act No. 206 (2d Cir. 2010). Â On September 13, 2017Â the SEC filed a complaint in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, N.Y. alleging that, among other things, that the defendants violated the securities registration provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17
